description: The Chacha Tower is a distinctive 25-meter high clock tower located on Batumi's Black Sea waterfront in Miracle Park. Completed in 2012, it is a faithful replica of an Ottoman-style clock tower that stood in Batumi at the beginning of the 20th century, originally designed by French architect Raymond Pere in 1901. The tower was conceived as a unique attraction featuring fountains that would dispense Georgia's national spirit, chacha, making it one of the world's most unusual public monuments.
highlights: 25-meter tall clock tower with observation platform offering panoramic views of Batumi's coastline
Replica of early 20th century Ottoman-style architecture with main dome at 25m and four smaller domes at 5m
Clock mechanism installed at 18-meter height (though currently not operational)
Originally featured fountains designed to dispense free chacha to visitors
Surrounded by four decorative pools with circulation systems
Located in scenic Miracle Park near the Ferris wheel and seaport
Cost 1 million Georgian lari (approximately $324,000 USD) to construct
tips: Visit in the evening or at night when the lighting creates a spectacular atmosphere
Climb to the observation platform for excellent views of Batumi's coastline and the Black Sea
Located near Ferris wheel and seaport at Gogebashvili Street - easy to combine with other waterfront attractions
Note: The chacha fountains have not been operational since 2015 - don't expect free chacha
The tower has become somewhat neglected with minimal maintenance; the clock no longer works
Free to visit and walk around the exterior; great photo opportunity especially at sunset
Best combined with a stroll along Batumi Boulevard and Miracle Park
vibe: Historic and quirky - a whimsical tribute to Georgian drinking culture that has become a neglected but charming landmark. The tower represents Batumi's ambitious efforts to create unique tourist attractions, blending traditional architecture with contemporary novelty. While the original concept of free-flowing chacha fountains no longer operates, the tower remains a distinctive symbol of Georgian hospitality and the country's deep-rooted relationship with its national spirit. The waterfront location provides a romantic setting, especially when illuminated at night, though visitors should adjust expectations knowing the interactive element is no longer functional.

historical_background.original_tower: The first Chacha tower was built on the seashore more than 100 years ago at the beginning of the 20th century
historical_background.architectural_inspiration: Designed as a replica of the Ottoman-style clock tower in Izmir, Turkey, originally created by French architect Raymond Pere in 1901
historical_background.reconstruction: Completed in 2012 as part of Batumi's waterfront revitalization project
historical_background.funding: The Batumi city council invested 1 million Georgian lari (approximately $324,000 USD) in the project
historical_background.purpose: Created to honor Georgian chacha tradition and serve as a tourist attraction with functional fountains dispensing the spirit

chacha_drink_facts.what_it_is: Georgia's national alcoholic spirit, a clear pomace brandy distilled from grape residue (seeds, skins, and stems) left over from winemaking
chacha_drink_facts.history: First distilled over 1000 years ago in Georgia
chacha_drink_facts.alcohol_content: Ranges from 40% for commercial varieties to 85% for homemade versions
chacha_drink_facts.similar_spirits: Comparable to Italian grappa, both being pomace brandies
chacha_drink_facts.cultural_significance: Staple at Georgian feasts and celebrations, embodying Georgian hospitality and shared cultural experience
chacha_drink_facts.georgian_winemaking: Part of Georgia's 8000-year winemaking tradition, inextricably linked to Georgian culture and identity
chacha_drink_facts.production_method: Made from pomace (grape residue), the pulpy byproduct of wine production

fountain_tradition.original_schedule: Originally planned to dispense chacha daily at 19:00 for 10-15 minutes, or once weekly
fountain_tradition.current_status: Fountains have not operated since 2015; they no longer dispense chacha or even water
fountain_tradition.design_intent: Schedule was kept somewhat irregular to prevent long queues from forming
fountain_tradition.significance: Was perhaps the biggest move to put chacha on the global map when announced in 2012
fountain_tradition.reality: The ambitious concept never achieved long-term success; the tower now serves primarily as a photogenic landmark

visitor_information.location: Miracle Park, Batumi Boulevard waterfront, Gogebashvili Street, near Ferris wheel and seaport
visitor_information.observation_platform: Available at the top with views of Batumi's entire coastline
visitor_information.admission: Free access to exterior and surrounding area
visitor_information.current_condition: Somewhat neglected with minimal maintenance; clock no longer functional; fountains inactive

interesting_facts: One of the world's most unusual public monuments, originally designed to dispense free alcohol
The tower is an exact replica of a structure that stood in Batumi over 100 years ago
Design is based on the Ottoman-style clock tower in Izmir, Turkey, from 1901
Chacha has been produced in Georgia for over 1000 years, predating modern distillation techniques
Georgia has an 8000-year winemaking tradition, making it one of the world's oldest wine regions
The tower cost over $300,000 USD to build, reflecting Batumi's investment in unique tourist attractions
Despite the fountains no longer working, the tower remains a popular photo spot and landmark
The concept was so ambitious it briefly became an international news story when announced
